results.title: Le Passager de la Pluie = Passengers of the Rain
results.brief_description:
Melie kills the stalker who assaulted and raped her and then disposes of the body. When the body is recovered, Dobbs, an American military officer accuses Melie of the murder and of stealing the US Army money that the rapist had been carrying with him. Awards: Golden Globe 1971 for Best Foreign Film.

Credits: Producer, Serge Silberman ; director, Rene Clement ; writers, Sebastien Japrisot, Lorenzo Ventavoli ; photography, Andreas Winding ; music, Francis Lai.
Cast: Marlene Jobert, Charles Bronson, Annie Cordy, Jean Gaven, Gabriele Tinti, Jean Piat, Jill Ireland, Corrine Marchand.

results.title: Un Enfant Dans la Foule = a Child in the Crowd
results.brief_description:
In 1937, Paul is a boarder in a religious institution. He suffers greatly from being separated from his mother and lets his school grades slip. During the Occupation, he becomes the pet of German soldiers, running errands for them. Later, he helps the Resistance, and when the Americans come to stay, he is really in his element with them. The films chronicles Paul’s attempts to fit in and connect with an authority figure.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Gerard Blain ; writers, Gerard Blain, Michel Perez ; photography, Emmanuel Machuel ; music, Jean Schwarz.
Cast: Jean-Francois Cimino, Cesar Chauveau, Annie Kovacs, Claire Treille, Jean Bertal.

results.title: Le Dialogue des Carmelites = the Carmelites
results.creator_credit: Philippe Agostini, R.L. Bruckberger and Pierre Laurent
results.brief_description:
Two young carmelite novices take the veil almost on the eve of the French Revolution, and find themselves, their sister nuns and the convent itself caught up in the political events that follow.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Laurent ; director, Philippe Agostini, R. L. Bruckberger ; writers, Philippe Agostini, R. L. Bruckberger, Georges Bernanos ; photography, Andre Bac ; music, Jean Francaix.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Alida Valli, Pascale Audret, Madeleine Renaud, Pierre Brasseur, Georges Wilson.

results.title: La Vie de Famille
results.brief_description:
Emmanuel lives with his second wife, Mara, and her 20 year old daughter, Natacha. The relationship between Emmanuel and his step-daughter are tense, and an argument erupts just when Emmanuel is about to go and join his first wife, Lili and his young daughter Elise for the week-end. Emmanuel and Elise take a trip from the south of France into Spain, working on a film project. Through a series of round-about conversations, Emmanuel manages to open up a few channels of communication with Elise — channels that expand even wider when he uses the technique of talking into her video camera to express thoughts and feelings that otherwise would have remained hidden.

Credits: Producer, Jean-Francois Lepetit ; director, Jacques Doillon ; writers, Jacques Doillon, Jean-Francois Goyet ; photography, Michel Carre.
Cast: Sami Frey, Mara Goyet, Juliet Berto, Juliette Binoche, Aina Walle.

results.title: Casque D'or = Golden Marie
results.creator_credit: Jacques Becker, Michel Safre, Raymond Hakim and Robert Hakim
results.brief_description:
n turn-of-the-century Paris an honest carpenter, is drawn into a world of pimps, prostitutes and petty crooks (‘Apaches’ as they were called at the time), because of his passion for ganster’s moll Marie. Becker’s lovingly recreated Paris of the past almost equals the radiance of Renoir, both father and son. [Becker worked as Jean Renoir’s assistant] Despite the ‘crime passionnel’ plot, the film is an affirmation of love and friendship. ‘Casque d’Or’ is primarily a film of personalities, but it is also a visual tour de force: a dance, brawl in the backyard, an awakening in the countryside, Manda’s arrival at the guillotine supported by a priest - these images are like magazine covers. This visual enchantment confirms me in my conviction that cinema is a popular art, and that it deceives itself when it tries to bring the paintings of the masters to life. ‘Casque d’Or’, at times funny, at times tragic, proves that we can surpass parody; we can look at the picturesque and bloody past and evoke it with tenderness and violence by means of a refined use of tone changes”. Reference: Francois Truffaut. ‘The films in my life’. Da Capo Press, 1994. Completed in 1951, ‘Casque D’Or’ was a failure on its first release, but then built up an excellent word-of-mouth reputation abroad. Awards: BAFTA Awards 1952: Best Actress for Simone Signoret.

Credits: Producer, Robert and Raymond Hakim, Michel Safre; director, Jacques Becker ; writers, Jacques Becker, Jacques Companeez ; photography, Robert Le Febvre ; music, Georges van Parys ; editor, Marguerite Renoir ; art direction, Jean d’Eaubonne.
Cast: Simone Signoret, Serge Reggianni, Claude Dauphin, Raymond Bussieres, Loleh Bellon, William Sabatier, Dominique Davray, Jean Clarieux.

results.title: Le Bossu = the Hunchback
results.brief_description:
Lagardere vows to protect Aurore, the baby daughter of his friend, Philippe de Nevers, who has just been murdered by his cousin Gonzague, who was coveting his fortune. Falsely accused of the murder, Lagardere swears he will seek to avenge his friend and help Aurore recover her fortune and rank in society. This favourite swashbuckling adventure has also been filmed by Andre Hunebelle (1960) and Philippe de Broca (1997).

Credits: Producer, Jason Regina ; director, Jean Delannoy ; writer, Bernard Zimmer ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Georges Auric.
Cast: Paul Bernard, Pierre Blanchar, Yvonne Gaudeau, Jean Marchat, Lucien Nat, Helene Vercors.

results.title: A Nous la Liberte = Freedom for Us
results.brief_description:
Two convicts, Louis and Emile, escape from prison, but Emile is recaptured. Louis makes his way into the world and advances from gramophone salesman to owner of a huge, modern gramophone factory. When Emile is released, he joins is old cellmate at the plant. After things go wrong, they take to the road together as tramps. Clair has created a sublime musical comedy satire on the work ethics and the dehumanizing effects of mass-production techniques. The film inspired Chaplin’s ‘Modern times’, in which there are similar sequences on the assembly line. Danger in ‘A nous la liberte’ often comes in the form of prophetic images of militaristic domination: the factory guards wear proto-fascist armbands and uniforms. The film equates authoritarianism with capitalist exploitation of the working class. Emile’s one time fellow prisoner, Louis becomes a wealthy industrialist and builds a factory modelled on the prison from which he once escaped. But Emile is the Dada remedy to Louis’s capitalist order. Everywhere he goes, straight lines collapse in confusion and mass production comes to a standstill.” Reference: Alan Williams. ‘Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking’. Harvard University Press, 1992.

Credits: Producer, Frank Clifford ; director, Rene Clair ; writer, Rene Clair ; photography, Georges Perinal ; music, Georges Auric ; art direction, Lazare Meerson.
Cast: Raymond Cordy, Henri Marchand, Rolla France, Paul Olivier, Jacques Shelly, Andre Michaud.

results.title: The Au Harem D'archimede = Tea in the harem
results.brief_description:
“The narrative centers on the adventures of a couple of eighteen-year-olds, Madjid, a Beur and Pat, his illiterate French friend. However, the loose episodic structure of the narrative, covering a week or so in the lives of people living on the ironically named Flowers Estate, allows other stories to be intercalated, particularly that of Josette, a single mother who loses her job and is driven to attempt suicide, and Malika, Madjid’s mother, who not only holds her own family together, but also provides support for other women on the estate who are unable to cope. The film is primarily interested in exploring Madjid’s conflicts of identity, torn between the (unrealistic) expectations his mother has of him as an Algerian and his experiences on the streets of Paris with Pat.” Reference: Carrie Tarr. Questions of identity in Beur cinema: from ‘Tea in the Harem’ to ‘Cheb’. Screen 34:4 (Winter 1993).Awards: Prix Jean Vigo 1984.

Credits: Producer, Michele Ray-Gavras ; director, Mehdi Charef ; writer, Mehdi Charef ; photography, Dominique Chapuis ; music, Karim Kacel
Cast: Kader Boukhanef, Remi Martin, Laure Duthilleul, Saida Bekkouche, Nicole Hiss.

results.title: Le Voleur de Crimes = the Crime Thief
results.brief_description:
An unhappily married man with two children watches a beautiful woman kill herself when she ties herself inside a car and drives off a cliff. Jean tries to save the woman but it is too late. After hanging out with his bohemian friends, he writes a letter to the local newspaper saying that he killed the woman. Jean is galvanized by the sensationalism of the headlines and becomes intoxicated with thoughts of murder. He does away with the pretty model and girlfriend of his painter friend in a similar manner. Soon the painter grows suspicious of Jean and believes he is the one who has sent the letters to the paper telling the story of a little man who gains self importance by murder.

Credits: Producer, Alain Queffelean ; director, Nadine Trintignant ; writer, Nadine Trintignant ; photography, Pierre Villemin ; music, Jack Arel ; assistant director, Daniel Vigne.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant ; Robert Hossein, Florinda Bolkan, Serge Marquand, Bernadette Lafont, Tanya Lopert, Georgia Moll, Karen Blanguernon, Francis Girod.

results.title: Le Cave Se Rebiffe = the Counterfeiters
results.brief_description:
A small-time crook, together with a couple of friends, plans a forgery operation using the skills of Robert, an engraver and the husband of his mistress. A professional mastermind is persuaded out of retirement to run the racket, and he and Robert double-cross the others to make off with the loot. This film gave an opportunity to Michel Audiard and Albert Simonin to write finely chiselled dialogues, filled with ‘argot’ and unforgettable one-liners

Credits: Producer, Jacques Bar ; director, Gilles Grangier ; writers, Albert Simonin, Michel Audiard, Gilles Grangier ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Francis Lemarque, Michel Legrand ; art direction, Jacques Colombier.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Maurice Biraud, Martine Carol, Bernard Blier, Francoise Rosay, Ginette Leclerc, Robert Dalban, Franck Willard, Antoine Balpetre, Albert Dinan.
